content.content: There are a lot of revenue generating and growth ideas flowing through the forum and polls with the main target to increase surplus buffer and hit the 250M goal. This post is not to criticize or rush into burning MKR (IMO it does not make sense to burn right now even though MKR price has declines) but to understand perspectives on when would be an appropriate time to do so. Below are a few thought-provoking questions regarding burning MKR.  When will surplus buffer be sufficient to start thinking about MKR burn? When the surplus buffer is sufficient, what would be the appropriate burn mechanism? A portion of stability or liquidation fees allocated to burn? Turning on PSM fees to burn? When the surplus buffer is sufficient, should new products include a revenue share for MKR burn? E.g. Revenue split for Vault X will be 95% to surplus buffer and 5% to burn MKR Is there a CU whose mandate includes analyzing MKR burn or issuances? How was the current surplus buffer goal (i.e. 250M) determined? Is the figure analyzed on a periodic frequency (e.g. Annually)?   Screenshot_20220802-094036_Chrome1080×1083 102 KB

These are important questions, and I think the first section of the last bullet should be what we’re answering first - how was the current surplus determined, and is that a reasonable level for the current market environment and/or future market environments?  Does the surplus need to be adjusted at assessment dates (is analysis on an annual basis frequent enough)? Can the burn occur via multiple mechanisms?  Would there be some logic to apportioning burn to various sources? Apologies, lots of questions and no suggestions, but I like these trains of thought!

TRUEMAKER:  When will surplus buffer be sufficient to start thinking about MKR burn?   At this point in time, with the market conditions as they are, I have a hard time even grasping when it might be sufficient. I’m looking forward to reading what others have to say but I don’t know that we are anywhere close unfortunately.

It depends on how many assets we want to deploy into RWAs and how liquid those deals will be, plus the burn rate of expenses. If we want to deploy billions into RWAs, the our surplus buffer should be in the hundreds of millions. Now, maybe it is worth burning a token amount of maker for marketing purposes.

Well, by itself the Maker burns were paralyzed, they don’t have the same media impact to do it in a bear market as in a bull market, what I like is the idea that if it were to burn, use it for advertising, but we can encompass the advertising in countries with emerging economies, which really need a stable currency as an alternative to their local currency

Rachel_G:  Does the surplus need to be adjusted at assessment dates (is analysis on an annual basis frequent enough)?   I think it should be adjusted as asset gets allocated to different initiatives or vault composition (i.e. DAI generation) materially shifts. E.g. 80% of DAI is backed by USDC vs non stable coins.     CodeKnight:  If we want to deploy billions into RWAs, the our surplus buffer should be in the hundreds of millions.   That is what I was thinking as well. The 250M surplus buffer was probably the goal before a lot of asset deployment proposals passed so the goal might shift higher to mitigate liquidity amd credit risk. If we are able to look into how the 250M was derived we could overlay the new proposals to determine the new goal.

CodeKnight:  Now, maybe it is worth burning a token amount of maker for marketing purposes.   What about increasing the USDC/DAI LP from 1bps to 2bps and negotiate with Uniswap that the extra fees will be used to burn 50%/50% UNI and MKR. I am reading that the UNIDAO is looking for ways to generate favorable tokenomics.

I encourage you to read the ALM forecast. The Surplus Buffer will soon limit our ability to generate revenues. Not saying there is a right or wrong answer but providing a lens to see the problem. Oh that graph makes sense now! Thanks for the explanation. That is a very important concern and definitely may constrain future growth. Maybe its just my POV from in forum discussions but I have not seen much discussion around the DAO getting close to the CaR/SB ratio limit on how that can impact future MIPs, etc. When the CaR = SB, should there be an automatic pause of additional investments? Seems that living in a CaR > SB would be very risky. I understand the CaR for crypto vaults, crypto assets and private credit but not really sure how it is derived for public credit (Bond ETFs). Since the public credit strategy is mostly in liquid ETFs is the CaR basically the potential 1-year capital depreciation? Noticed its ranging from 1.6% - 2.1%.

TRUEMAKER:  Since the public credit strategy is mostly in liquid ETFs is the CaR basically the potential 1-year capital depreciation? Noticed its ranging from 1.6% - 2.1%.   Yes indeed, there we have a good history to create a backtest. You can find more on the model here. For RWA that are less diversified (like 3-4 loans for a RWA vault), it is less statistically relevant. Formula is more Basel III driven.     TRUEMAKER:  When the CaR = SB, should there be an automatic pause of additional investments? Seems that living in a CaR > SB would be very risky.   Maker was run with CaR > SB for quite some time, there was a sudden shift to safety earlier this year when there was a flap issue. MKR holders decide. The key point is that : revenue is linked to risk taken that requires surplus buffer. Notice as well that for a long time we underdelivered growth on the asset side and we are still 80% stablecoin-backed.

TRUEMAKER:  When the CaR = SB, should there be an automatic pause of additional investments? Seems that living in a CaR > SB would be very risky.   CaR > SB is common among growth companies and its sustainable as long as DAI adoption and Vault usage continues to increase. With current market conditions we should try to remain closer to the SB. In crisis mode, more important is the DAO’s ability to meet its financial obligations (withdrawals) by having sufficient liquid DAI without having to resort to lender of last resort (MKR issuance).

SebVentures:  Maker was run with CaR > SB for quite some time, there was a sudden shift to safety earlier this year when there was a flap issue. MKR holders decide.   I think it is fair to argue that the flight to safety was mainly driven by vault holders reducing their exposure.

JustinCase:  I think it is fair to argue that the flight to safety was mainly driven by vault holders reducing their exposure   Vault holders got liquidated due to market conditions.     SebVentures:  The key point is that : revenue is linked to risk taken that requires surplus buffer. Notice as well that for a long time we underdelivered growth on the asset side and we are still 80% stablecoin-backed.   Getting back to the original question, based on the CaR forecast the SB goal for 2023 yearend should be 140M. I think we can do it, especially if rates continue to rise. More importantly If we reach that goal, we can ignite the MKR burn discussions again.

TRUEMAKER:  This post is not to criticize or rush into burning MKR (IMO it does not make sense to burn right now even though MKR price has declines) but to understand perspectives on when would be an appropriate time to do so.   There were quite a few interesting comments in this direction in this thread earlier this year: [Signal Request] Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation & Resurrect the Burn Also some helpful technical recommendations/points from Risk, ie:    [Signal Request] Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation & Resurrect the Burn   We are proposing burning MKR based on specifications listed below using the newly released DssKiln  by the PECU. A predetermined amount of dai would be vested from the SB to the contract for the predetermined duration, which would then market buy MKR tokens directly from Uniswap v3 MKR/ETH (0.3% fee) in predetermined dai amounts based on specifications below and burn them by calling the MKR token burn(). The vesting option was chosen to enable governance to cancel the stream and essentially shut down the operation in the case it underperforms or a technical issue is uncovered. The negative side of the vesting solution is that it is much more gas intensive compared to a single deposit solution. Once the operation is tested, governance can change how the contract is funded and lower the keeper cost and ensure the community and market participants that burn will continue. There are possible unwanted instances, such as MEV and similar blockchain based market activity specific risks and griffing attacks, but we believe that the potential benefits of this SR outweighs the unwanted results. The proposed parameters for the permissionless open market operation are designed in a risk and unwanted outcomes minimization manner.   Would +1 @SebVentures’ point above as well about the ALM forecast. I think burn discussions in general are tricky in the community because they touch on a relatively beloved traditional Maker feature (ie, the burn) but the analysis is necessarily complicated by macro, ALM, technical points etc. It’s possible that the broad enthusiasm seen earlier in the year to restart the burn has waned somewhat with the arrival of the bear.
